awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a 400 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) Spectrometer to Advance Research and Student Research Training at the University of Scranton
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation program.  The University of Scranton is acquiring a 400 MHz nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrometer that has the capabilities to perform both routine analysis and more complex experiments that helps elucidate molecular structures of chemical compounds.  The instrument supports the research of Professor Michael Fennie and colleagues Arthur Catino and Nicholas Sizemore at the University of Scranton and several collaborators at other colleges and universities in the Scranton region.   Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research.  This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of undergraduate and graduate students in chemistry.  This instrument is a regional resource in the Scranton area, with users coming from local industry and high school science classes, in addition to other colleges in the region.

The award of the NMR spectrometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels.  It especially impacts the development of methodologies to facilitate the structure elucidation of small and medium-sized molecules.  This spectrometer allows research in a variety of fields such as catalysis, biophysical structural analysis, development of synthetic methodology, synthesis of both natural and synthetic products and organometallic chemistry.  In general, NMR spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structures of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution or in the solid state.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The University of Scranton, a primarily-undergraduate, comprehensive university serving over 3,600 undergraduates located in Scranton Pennsylvania, acquired a new Bruker 400 MHz AVANCE nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrometer, replacing a 30-year-old NMR system that was functionally outdated, frequently broke down, and was long unsupported by the manufacturer. This new state-of-the-art instrument, with much-improved detection and throughput capabilities, has increased the productivity of faculty research and enhanced the research-training of undergraduate and master’s students as they prepare for STEM careers in academia or industry. 

The NMR spectrometer has enabled research in a number of areas at the University of Scranton. Some of the major projects supported by the instrument are: 

The Hydroamination project, which focuses on creating a versatile and gentle method for the hydroamination of terminal alkynes containing pendant imino groups, leading to the synthesis of various non-aromatic "dihydroheterocycle" classes. These dihydroheterocycles can then undergo further functionalization through reactions that convert them into aromatic molecules. Such molecules will find use in the pharmaceutical inductry.

The Tryptophan project, which seeks to establish streamlined methods for synthesizing labeled (CN-, N3-) amino acids, enabling their incorporation into peptides and proteins through solid-phase peptide synthesis. Such molecular probes are intended to help study protein folding.

The Tetraarylmethane project, which focuses on developing innovative methods for synthesizing organic optoelectronic materials, particularly tetraarylmethanes (TAMs). TAMs are robust, three-dimensional molecules with a central carbon atom bonded to four aryl groups. They have diverse applications, including in organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), organic solar cells, hydrogen storage systems, and drug delivery technologies.

Other projects using the NMR involve the synthesis of gold nanoparticles, and the chemical recycling of polystyrene. In addition to being used extensively in independent student and faculty research activities, the NMR has been infused across the curriculum into training-laboratory coursework for undergraduate and masters students.

To date, 32 individuals—including four faculty members, five graduate students, and 23 undergraduates—have been trained to use the NMR spectrometer for their independent research projects which have or will culminate in research theses. This training covers sample preparation, spectral acquisition, and data analysis using software programs such as TopSpin or MestReNova.

Additionally, 98 students enrolled in advanced chemistry courses (CHEM 370L: Instrumental Analysis, CHEM 470L: Forensic Chemistry, CHEM 444L: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry, and CHEM 571: Analytical Methods) receive similar training and incorporate the NMR into their laboratory coursework. In the introductory organic chemistry sequence, students are introduced to the instrument through demonstrations during lecture and hands-on preparation of NMR samples in the laboratory, with spectra interpretation as part of their exercises.

On the broader impacts and outreach front, the NMR has been integrated into the University's "University of Success" program, which enrolls high school students from all parts of Northeastern Pennsylvania. The University of Success was founded in 1996 in response to the growing trend of lower graduation rates and stagnant college enrollment rates for young people who are often underserved or underrepresented in the higher education process. Through creative and innovative programming and services, this early intervention program aims to encourage and motivate students to expand their horizons to include the goal of attending college, an aspiration that many of the students and their families may not have thought possible. An experiential learning module using the NMR has been developed and implemented in this program over the past few summers.


Last Modified: 11/27/2024
Modified by: Michael Fennie
